description.p: A class based on the sorcerer, the metamorph can be used alongside the normal sorcerer or as a replacement for it. In this document, I've opted to replace the sorcerer's bulky resource systems entirely with more at-will abilities. To do so, I reduced the class's spellcasting abilities and gave it several new features. This also warranted a new name, and comes with some interesting tricks I'll detail below.

Instead of sorcerous origins, you pick the forms that your ancestor's physiology and powers took. These forms will make themselves known to the world, as your physically transform into an amalgam of your race and your ancestor's, which grants you some of their powers. These effects will seem familiar to sorcerer players, but many of them are brand new options that I've carefully crafted.

With Innate Spellcasting, you choose a spell at each of the same levels that a half-caster would gain a new spell. You can cast each of these spells once per long rest that you take. The gap created here is covered with abilities granted by your ancestral form, as well as with willpower.

Willpower is an adapted version of sorcery points that you can use to cast your innate spells beyond their lowest level. There are a few features that allow you to spend willpower on them, as well, but most have been tweaked or eliminated. The unique part of this is that you can cast your innate spells beyond 5th level in this manner. You can't learn 6th to 9th level spells, but that doesn't mean you can't cast them!

Beyond these major changes, there are several new features in the class and the ancestral forms that fill in the half-caster progression and that allow you the freedom to easily shape your magic. Enjoy!

The most important question to consider when creating your metamorph is the origin of your power. As a starting character, you'll choose an origin that ties to an ancestral bloodline, but the exact source of your power is up to you to decide. Is it a family curse, passed down to you from distant ancestors? Or did some extraordinary event leave you blessed with inherent magic but perhaps scarred as well?

How do you feel about the magical power coursing through you? Do you embrace it, try to master it, or revel in its unpredictable nature? Is it a blessing or a curse? Did you seek it out, or did it find you? Did you have the option to refuse it, and do you wish you had? What do you intend to do with it? Perhaps you feel like you’ve been given this power for some lofty purpose. Or you might decide that the power gives you the right to do what you want, to take what you want from those who lack such power. Perhaps your power links you to a powerful individual in the world—the fey creature that blessed you at birth, the dragon who put a drop of its blood into your veins, the lich who created you as an experiment, or the deity who chose you to carry this power.

You can make a metamorph quickly by following these suggestions. First, Charisma should be your highest ability score, followed by Constitution. Second, choose the hermit background. Third, choose the light, prestidigitation, ray of frost, and shocking grasp cantrips, along with the 1st-level spell magic missile.
As an metamorph, you gain the following class features.

description.p: The Player's Handbook contains rules for multiclassing, which allows you to create a character with levels in more than one class. The following rules are added to the Spellcasting section.

Spell Slots. If you have the Innate Spellcasting feature, whenever you require a spell slot for one of your spells or features, you can instead expend the use of one of your spells from Innate Spellcasting to create a spell slot of the same level as the expended spell.

Overfocus. Whenever you use a a spell from your Innate Spellcasting feature to create a spell slot, you can also expend willpower to increase the level of the slot. You must still follow the other rules of the Overfocus feature.
An event in your past, or in the life of a parent or ancestor, left an indelible mark on you, infusing you with arcane magic. This magic, whatever its origin, fuels your spells.

At 1st level, you know four cantrips of your choice from the metamorph spell list. You learn more metamorph cantrips of your choice at higher levels, as shown in the Cantrips Known column of the metamorph table.
description.h5: INNATE SPELLS OF 1ST LEVEL AND HIGHER
description.p: Choose one 1st-level spell from the metamorph spell list. You can cast the chosen spell once without expending a spell slot, and you must finish a long rest before you can do so again. You can forego the material components for spells you cast in this way, unless they have a cost or are consumed by the spell. When you gain a level in this class, you can choose one of these metamorph spells and replace it with another spell from the metamorph spell list, which must be of the same spell level as the spell you're replacing.

You can choose an additional metamorph spell to cast in this way at each of the metamorph levels shown in the Innate Spells table. The same spell can be chosen again, which allows you to cast it an additional time. The spells you choose must also be of a level no greater than the spell level shown in the Innate Spells table.

Charisma is your spellcasting ability for your metamorph spells, since the power of your magic relies on your ability to project your will into the world. You use your Charisma whenever a spell refers to your spellcasting ability. In addition, you use your Charisma modifier when setting the saving throw DC for a metamorph spell you cast and when making an attack roll with one.
Spell save DC = 8 + your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier
Spell attack modifier = your proficiency bonus + your Charisma modifier
Choose an ancestral form, which describes the source of your innate magical power, such as Draconic Bloodline.

Your choice grants you features when you choose it at 1st level and again at 6th, 14th, and 18th level. It also determines the transformations that your body undertakes when you cast spells. When you cast a metamorph spell of 1st level or higher, you take on the first form available to you for your chosen Ancestral Form. This form lasts for a number of minutes equal to the spell's level.

description.p: Also at 2nd level, you gain the ability to twist your spells to suit your needs. You gain one of the following options of your choice. You gain an additional option of your choice at 5th level, 11th level, and 17th level. When you gain a level in this class, you can choose to replace one of your current Metamagic options with another one.
You can use only one Metamagic option on a spell when you cast it, unless otherwise noted. Some Metamagic options have a level requirement; such a requirement refers to your level in this class.

sheet.description: You can apply one Metamagic option on a spell when you cast it, unless otherwise noted.
You can apply up to two Metamagic options on a spell when you cast it.

description.p: At 3rd level, you can exert your will to evoke more magic with your spells, increasing their potency.

You have 3 willpower, a measure of your ability to withstand the stress of forcefully evoking powerful magic. Your total willpower increases as you gain levels, as shown in the the metamorph table. You regain all of your spent willpower when you finish a long rest.

Whenever you cast one of your innate spells, you can also expend your available willpower to increase the spell's level by the amount of willpower spent. However, you can't cause the level of the spell to exceed half your metamorph level, rounded up, or 9th level (whichever is lower), even if you have the willpower to do so. For example, a level 5 metamorph can cast chromatic orb as a 3rd-level spell by expending 2 willpower when casting it.
When you use this feature on a spell that causes you to assume your ancestral form, you also take on the second form listed in the feature's description.

description.p: When you reach 4th level, and again at 8th, 12th, 16th, and 19th level, you can increase one ability score of your choice by 2, or you can increase two ability scores of your choice by 1. As normal, you can't increase an ability score above 20 using this feature.
At 7th level, you can draw out endurance through a careful surge of magic.
You can use your bonus action to touch a willing creature and expend 1 willpower. The creature expends a hit die, rolling it and gaining hit points equal to the result + your Charisma modifier.

description.p: At 10th level, you gain finer control of your spells, allowing you to apply up to two metamagic options you know to spells you cast.
At 15th level, with some mental effort, you can flow excess magical energy into others.

You can use your action to touch a creature that has the ability to use spell slots and expend an amount of willpower no greater than your Charisma modifier. When you do, that creature regains one of its expended spell slots of a level equal to the willpower you spent.
Once you've used this feature, you must finish a short or long rest before you can use it again.

description.p: When you awaken this ancestral form at 1st level, some of your ancestors' traits begin to manifest upon you. The following forms are available to you:

Invasive Thoughts. While you are in this form, you can communicate telepathically with any creature that's within 60 feet of you. A creature that knows at least one language can reply in a way you understand. You determine the tone and pitch of your voice when you communicate telepathically in this way.

As a bonus action while in this form, you can force one creature within range of your telepathy to make an Intelligence saving throw. On a failed save, you plant the seed of a devastating thought in its mind; the first time the creature is hit with an attack or fails a saving throw before the start of your next turn, the creature also takes psychic damage equal to 1d6 + your spellcasting ability modifier. The damage increases by 1d6 when you reach 11th level in this class. Regardless of whether the target succeeds or fails, it doesn't know you attempted to influence its mind.

At 14th level, the magical power within you fully awakens. You can cause all of your ancestral forms to last 1 hour by expending 1 willpower when you take one of your forms. Additionally, whenever you assume an ancestral form, you also assume the following form:

Revelation In Flesh. This form unleashes the aberrant truth hidden within your flesh. As a bonus action, you can spend 1 willpower to magically transform your body, gaining one of the following benefits of your choice, the effects of which last while you are in this form:

ul.li: You gain a swimming speed equal to your walking speed and the ability to breathe water. Gills grow from your neck or fan out from behind your ears, your fingers become webbed, or you grow lashing cilia that extend through your clothing.
You gain a flying speed equal to your walking speed and can hover. As you fly, your skin glistens with mucus.

Your body, along with any equipment you are wearing or carrying, becomes slimy and pliable. You can move through any space as narrow as 1 inch without squeezing, and you can spend 5 feet of movement to escape from nonmagical restraints or being grappled.
Your eyes turn black or become writhing sensory tendrils. You know the location of any hidden or invisible creature within 60 feet of you.

This might take the form of a sphere of rippling psychic energy, a fluctuating amoebic gel, an extrusion of ephemeral parasites, or some other manifestation. Other creatures treat the aura as difficult terrain, and when they start their turn in it, they take 2d10 psychic damage. When you activate this feature, you can choose any number of creatures you can see to be unaffected by the aura.

As a bonus action, you can end the aura early. If you do so, you and any number of creatures you choose within the aura are teleported to a location you can see within 1 mile of you. Each creature must appear within 20 feet of you and in an unoccupied space. An unwilling creature that succeeds on a Charisma saving throw against your spell save DC is not teleported.
Once you use this feature, you can’t use it again until you finish a long rest.

description.p: Your innate magic is channeled through the planar pools which connect many of the planes of existence to the astral plane. Your soul has been split in two, with the majority of its essence - the "anchor" - bound to the astral plane. Many such souls never awaken their power, but through intense training, a near-death experience, or other elevating event, you have gained awareness and control of this flexible magic source.
Astral-bound Soul Features

Psychic Wind. Psychic wind whirls in an invisible, protective field around you, with visible tufts of psychic energy flowing from your body. Whenever you cast a metamorph spell after taking this form, you gain temporary hit points equal to the spell's level (0 if the spell is a cantrip) + your spellcasting ability modifier, and creatures within 5 feet of you take 3 psychic damage. This psychic damage increases at certain metamorph levels: 6 at 5th level, 9 at 11th level, and 12 at 17th level.

Dire Retreat. A silvery cloak drapes over your shoulders, around your neck, and trails behind you, fading to invisibility after 1 foot. While in this form, your link to your astral anchor is at its strongest. You have resistance to all damage while unconscious, and advantage on death saving throws. If you die while in this form, your body gains the benefits of the gentle repose spell.
